linkTarget.anchoringText: Nowadays more and more of resources being developed are hard-to-recover. One of the major hard-torecover categories is low-permeable formations. Developing low-permeable formation with traditional slanted wells systems is often inprofitable. Even massive fraccing of every well does not allow to develop formations with permeability less than 0.3 mD in current economical situation. The decision is drilling horizontals with multi-fracs. The number of such wells increases every year (Fig. 1.)

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Neseccity of surveillance and optimizing fractured horizontals

formatted-caption.caption-text: Neseccity of surveillance and optimizing fractured horizontals

linkTarget.anchoringText: Geological profile is clinoform, and productive layers are non-anticline, lithologically screened hydrocarbons deposits (Fig.2).

A pilot well was drilled, oriented to make fractures transversal to the wellbore. The productivity was high and decline rate was low, but eventually problem occurred with pressure maintenance. Placing injectors on the axis, crossing the producer wellbore leads to producer drowning due-to auto-frac effect (Fig. 3, left, wells 093, 296). Placing injectors outside this zone maintains pressure in only parts of the reservoir (Fig. 3, left, wells 095, 46, 244). Thus, in case of transversal fractures there is no safe way to provide an effective displacement. So the decision was made to use lateral fractures. It provides comparatively high productivity due to long fractures systems and at the same time prevent lateral coning (Fig. 3, right).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Typical displacement unit with multifracs (left – transversal fractures, right– lateral fractures)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical displacement unit with multifracs (left – transversal fractures, right– lateral fractures)

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, the surveillance of such wells is very difficult. For example, it takes over 3000 hrs of build-up to get a radial flow and estimate permeability, skin and fractures geometry. Thanks to PDG systems, we can use drowdown data with no need for stopping the well. Finally, it turned out, than these wells do not get pseudo-radial flow at all (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Surveillance results for one of multi-fracs, Cartesian and Log-Log

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surveillance results for one of multi-fracs, Cartesian and Log-Log

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pressure fields in time after well launch arer shown at Fig 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Fractured horizontals production simulation, pressure field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fractured horizontals production simulation, pressure field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pressure distribution shows that at early time fractures really work independently. It is easy to see that at this time the well works similarly to a well where several formations are exploited and fractured (Fig. 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Suggested approach to interpretation of well test in muli-frac

formatted-caption.caption-text: Suggested approach to interpretation of well test in muli-frac

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this case permeability calculated by this “early” radial flow (if it is detected) is N times multiplied formation permeability (where N being a number of producing fractures), while Xf is √N times multiplied average Xf. Let us have an example. Fig. 7 shows simulation results for case of 5 fractures, Fig.8 – real multi-frac log-log analysis.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Log-log analysis for a simulated 5-fractured horizontal

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log analysis for a simulated 5-fractured horizontal

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this case permeability calculated by this “early” radial flow (if it is detected) is N times multiplied formation permeability (where N being a number of producing fractures), while Xf is √N times multiplied average Xf. Let us have an example. Fig. 7 shows simulation results for case of 5 fractures, Fig.8 – real multi-frac log-log analysis.
To obtain a real production profile of a fractured horizontal a production logging was performed (Fig.9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: PL results in multifractured horizontal with use of FSI

formatted-caption.caption-text: PL results in multifractured horizontal with use of FSI

linkTarget.anchoringText: An example of such simulation is shown at Fig. 10. The result of this set of simulations was an optimal fractured horizontal design, well spacing between producers and injectors, and rows spacing, staying with drilling density and a concept of horizontal producers and slanted injectors.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: One of displacement unit geometry options simulation

formatted-caption.caption-text: One of displacement unit geometry options simulation
